repnme.cdata!: Bolivia - Social Safety Net SAC Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Social Safety Net SAC Project for
            Bolivia had the following ratings: the outcome was
            satisfactory, the sustainability was likely, the
            institutional development impact was high, and the Bank and
            borrower performance were both satisfactory. The lessons
            learned indicate that it is generally agreed that volatility
            (and periodic intra-year cuts) in funding for social
            protection programs should be avoided since it leads to
            inefficiency and ultimately substantial costs in terms of
            lost human capital development in the medium term. The use
            of well-defined indicators associated with the expected
            results helps not only the implementation of the credit, but
            the targeting of actions by the Government. The Social
            Safety Net Structural Adjusment Credit (SSNSAC) focused
            attention on a few well-selected programs that were closely
            aligned to the overall goal of the program-social protection
            in a time of fiscal constraints. A structural adjustment
            operation that involves a process of relatively complex
            change, such as the establishment of an effective social
            safety net, will be difficult to implement on an operational
            level. To improve the results of education and health
            services and of social protection programs and expand access
            to the most vulnerable populations (often indigenous
            peoples), awareness and training activities should be
            expanded through dialogue and focus groups mechanisms
            promoting the reduction of cultural impediments to accessing
            services. Technical assistance should be provided for the
            development of information systems, within the Information
            and Administrative Modernization System (SIGMA), so that
            better decisions can be adopted on the use of public
            resources and their follow-up at all levels of Government.

repnme.cdata!:
Bolivia - Social Safety Net Structural
            Adjustment Credit : Release of the second tranche, partial
            waiver of one condition, and full waiver of two conditions

abstracts.cdata!:
This release of the second tranche of
            the Social Safety Net Structural Adjustment Credit Project
            will support the Government of Bolivia to help it respond to
            urgent social needs and deepening fiscal pressures, both of
            which have been worsened by the recent civil conflict.
            Progress in implementing the credit has been impressive in
            light of the severe civil strife of October 2003, which
            brought most government programs to a standstill, and the
            subsequent change of Government which resulted in new
            leadership for all government entities and a reorganization
            of functions among them.  The Government remains on track
            for achievement of five of the six conditions before the
            closing date of the credit. A fill waiver for the budget
            execution condition is sought as the expected result will be
            a successful adaptation to challenging circumstances, and
            fully consistent with the intent of the target.  A partial
            waiver is requested for the progress report on impact
            evaluation condition as the impact evaluation is planned to
            begin early 2004.  A full waiver is also sought for the
            Education Sector Strategy to be presented to National
            Education Congress on the grounds that the civil strife led
            to a postponement of the Conference until March 2004.

5087057.majtheme: Social protection and risk management,Human development

repnme.cdata!:
Bolivia - Social Safety Net Structural
            Adjustment Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Bolivia has achieved remarkable progress
            in social indicators since the launch of it s far reaching
            economic and social reforms of the early 1990s. Those
            reforms, sustained and deepened in successive Governments up
            to the present, met with early success in stimulating
            growth, but the economy's performance stalled after
            1998, due to several causes, and poverty increased over the
            last 5 years. This eroded popular support for the reforms,
            and recently led to a serious episode of civil unrest. The
            Social Safety Net Structural Adjustment Credit, a
            two-tranche credit intended to be completed by March 2004,
            is a part of IDA'S immediate response package to the
            current social and economic crisis in Bolivia. The credit
            supports the Government's near term program of fiscal
            adjustment and provision of vital social safety net
            services. The credit thus will help the Government to close
            a financing gap in 2003, expand the provision of social
            services during this period of fiscal adjustment, contain
            erosion in social outcomes for the poor ,to address the
            economic underpinnings of rising social tensions.
            Specifically, the program would: (i) protect the budgets of
            nine key programs (National Emergency Employment Program,
            Health Reform, Epidemiological Shield for Chagas, Malaria,
            and Tuberculosis, Universal Health Insurance for Mother and
            Child Care, Expanded Immunization Program, Education Reform
            and Education Quality), that are subject to high volatility
            in investment budgets and expenditure execution and are key
            to the containment of further erosion of social outcomes and
            achievement of counter-cyclical goals of the 2003
            budget;(ii) sustain and, in some areas, strengthen key
            social sector reforms of this Government and it s
            predecessors; (iii)provide technical support over the
            bridging period (June2003 to March 2004) to protected social
            safety net programs. The time horizon is a bridging period
            of 9-10 months, during which stability, both social and
            fiscal, can be restored, and the foundations for medium term
            reform put in place.

Bolivia - Social Safety Net Structural
